I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Coordinating natural resource management for sustainable development is a strategic 
objective of the Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Philippines East Association of 
Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Growth Area (BIMP-EAGA) Road Map to Development 
(2006–2010). This objective is central to economic growth in the subregion, where production 
systems  are  largely  based  on  natural  resources.  Growth  must  also  be  sustainable  to 
drastically reduce the incidence of poverty, estimated at 50%.1 Sustainability rests on better 
management of the subregion’s natural resources, which are among the richest repositories of 
the earth’s biodiversity. The Sulu-Sulawesi Marine Ecoregion (SSME), at the center of the 
Coral Triangle, and the Heart of Borneo (HOB) are part of the growth area.2   
 
2.  The action plan of the BIMP-EAGA Road Map, released in 2006, calls for a natural 
resource management program for the subregion. The program is foreseen to cover joint 
environmental  protection  activities  particularly  in  border  areas,  projects  fostering 
complementary resource use among member countries, and activities in support of SSME and 
HOB, flagship projects of BIMP-EAGA. Such a program should strengthen the link between 
environmental protection and economic growth in BIMP-EAGA and also bring more coherence 
and synergy to multi-country agreements, plans, implementation mechanisms, and resources 
for the SSME and HOB, as well as for the ASEAN program that deals with the problem of 
trans-boundary haze. The urgent need for a BIMP-EAGA regional environment program (REP) 
was affirmed during the Fact-Finding Mission on 10–28 September 2007.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Unsustainable Use of Natural Resources. The natural resource base of the BIMP-
EAGA countries is in fast decline. Logging, mining, and farm expansion have deforested the 
uplands. Indonesia lost 64 million hectares of forest, or 60% of its total, between 1950 and 
2000, and the loss is continuing at the rate of 2 million hectares a year. Even forest under legal 
protection is not safe. Around 56% of protected lowland forest in Kalimantan, Indonesian 
Borneo,  was  wiped  out  between  1985  and  2001.  This  loss  only  intensifies  the  threat  of 
extinction  of  a  wide  range  of  life  forms  supported  by  the  forest.  Fires  caused  by  farm 
expansion have produced haze reaching as far as Singapore and the Philippines. In 1997 and 
1998, fires razed more than 3.2 million hectares of forestland in Kalimantan.  
 
4.  The sea is not faring any better. Fish stocks have diminished to unsustainable levels as 
a result of overfishing and the use of destructive fishing methods. The catch per unit effort in 
75% of fishing grounds in the Philippines has dropped so steeply that experts warn of a 
possible  crash  of  selected  stocks  in  the  next  10  years  unless  the  management  regime 
drastically improves.3  Around 70% of the SSME in the Philippines has been affected. Global 
warming, fed partly by the rise in carbon emissions and the decrease in carbon sinks,4 may 
hasten these losses through coral bleaching and ecological disequilibrium. The use of more 
fossil fuels as the subregion’s economy grows adds to carbon emissions, even as the forest

shrinks  and  there  is  less  carbon  sink  to  absorb  those  emissions.  While  the  current 
management of resources may bring short-term economic gains, it presents a long-term threat 
to 54 million people from over 350 ethno-linguistic groups. The very poor, who depend most 
heavily on natural resources for their livelihood, will bear the brunt. 
 
5.  Need  for  a  Strategic  Framework  for  Environmental  Conservation  in  the 
Subregion. The only policy instrument that guides natural resource management in BIMP-
EAGA is the Road Map to Development and its action plan. One of the six components of the 
action plan is sustainable development and environmental management by means of three 
strategies: (i) developing a framework for intra-EAGA cooperation in the integrated protection 
and management of natural resources and biodiversity; (ii) identifying and developing viable 
and sustainable joint investment projects in forestry, fishery, minerals, and energy; and (iii) 
encouraging and supporting greater private sector participation in sustainable natural resource 
development projects and environmental protection programs. The REP will carry out these 
strategies.  Without  the  REP,  BIMP-EAGA  has  no  standards  for  ensuring  that  its  natural 
systems have the regenerating capacity to match the resource extraction rate, and that it is 
equipped with the proper safeguards to avoid and mitigate adverse impact. 
 
6.  Three-country agreements for the management of SSME and HOB are in place. SSME 
has a conservation plan in varying stages of implementation in Indonesia, Malaysia, and the 
Philippines, and these countries are drawing up a conservation plan for HOB. The SSME 
conservation plan will have to be reviewed and revised in the light of the lessons learned from 
4 years of implementation, so that it complements more closely the BIMP-EAGA action plan. 
 
7.  Limited Resource Management Capacity. BIMP-EAGA is faced with a number of 
challenges in putting together an effective program for natural resource management, and 
strengthening coordination and cooperation among the many agencies that are responsible for 
the  environment  and  natural  resources.  The  complex  institutional  arrangements  for  the 
development of the subregion include the Business Council (BEBC), which represents the 
private sector. Lack of information on trade flows and trends in natural resource use hampers 
the  BEBC’s  capacity  to  coordinate  the  activities  of  private  investors  and  to  promote 
investments in environment and sustainable resource management. Eleven working groups 
made up of government and private sector representatives support program development and 
implementation. These are organized into four clusters; in the natural resources development 
cluster are working groups in agro-industry, fisheries cooperation, forestry and environment 
and energy, and human resource development.  
 
8.  The working groups are led by government staff who are only intermittently involved in 
BIMP-EAGA operations. The Facilitation Center and the BEBC secretariat are thinly staffed for 
routine administration; they can neither provide technical support for REP development and 
implementation nor effectively mobilize and coordinate support from donors. SSME and HOB, 
though flagship projects of BIMP-EAGA, have yet to receive concrete support from it. The 
SSME tri-national committee needs increased financial support for its regular functions. The 
HOB tri-national body, on the other hand, has yet to start operating. BIMP-EAGA is in a 
position to rally stakeholder groups to support its flagship projects, but it must have adequate 
resources and improved capability to do so. 
 
9.  Need  for  Sustainable  Financing  for  Environmental  Conservation.  BIMP-EAGA 
relies heavily on government funds to operate. Government agencies in the member countries 
draw from their limited budgets to fund their subregional activities. However, there is not 
enough government financing for sound environmental management. Similarly, private sector 
organizations depend on their own funds. Coordination and cooperation among donors must 
also improve to strengthen institutional support for environmental conservation in BIMP-EAGA.

3
10.  Some in government and the private sector see the need for a subregional fund facility 
to support activities particularly for the implementation of the development road map and 
action plan. The mechanics for the establishment of such a fund would have to be developed, 
especially if a long-term program for natural resource management is to be implemented and 
sustained. Given the varying levels of development and capacity of the member countries, the 
less adequately resourced cannot be expected to cover their cost of managing trans-boundary 
resources for the common benefit. The result of carrying out a program without such a fund is 
evident in SSME. Its program implementation was seriously impaired when the fund set aside 
for it by the Government of the Philippines was depleted and unreplenished, and even more so 
when supplementary funds from nongovernment organizations (NGOs) were reduced.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The regional technical assistance (RETA)5 will strengthen the sustainable management 
of natural resources in the BIMP-EAGA. It will produce an agreed design for a REP for BIMP-
EAGA. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  A program for the proposed implementation period of 15 years, in three 5-year cycles, 
will be prepared within 18 months (March 2008 to September 2009). The RETA will adopt the 
following strategies; it will (i) use research-based information to define options and make 
decisions  for  sustainable  resource  management;  (ii)  engage  multisector  and  multilevel 
stakeholder participation for broad-based program ownership and wider support; (iii) build on 
existing  policies,  plans,  intercountry  agreements,  institutional  arrangements,  and 
accomplishments to consolidate the gains and accelerate progress; (iv) secure the required 
long-term commitment from stakeholders and donors to sustain the program results in a large 
and complex implementation setting; and (v) consider fully the interaction of factors shaping 
common threats and opportunities for environmental protection to generate a coordinated and 
synergistic response for the subregion.6 The following activities will be carried out during 
program formulation: 
 
(i)  Activity  1:  Preparing  environmental  and  socioeconomic  profiles  of 
BIMP-EAGA. The profiles will be prepared to determine: (a) the environmental 
and socioeconomic characteristics of the member countries and the subregion, 
(b) common environmental issues and trends and the impact of socioeconomic 
activities on environmental degradation, (c) the issues that the BIMP-EAGA 
REP must address, and (d) the activities that will best support the BIMP-EAGA 
REP. A technical team will be formed in each member country for the purpose. 
The data will come mainly from secondary sources. Rapid appraisal methods 
may be applied to verify the secondary data and collect primary data. The 
country data will be consolidated into a subregional profile. The data will be 
translated into geographic information, using geographic information system 
(GIS) technology, to produce maps that reflect national and local jurisdictions, 
drainage, existing and planned land use, forest types, critical habitats, critical

species population and distribution, resource use by type, threats by source 
and type, routes of migratory species, existing initiatives by type, infrastructure, 
demographic distribution and density, ethnic distribution, economic production, 
and poverty incidence.  
 
(ii)  Activity  2:  Assessing  policies  and  institutional  capabilities.  The  policy 
assessment will cover the BIMP-EAGA development road map and action plan, 
policies of the BEBC, and multi-country agreements and plans for SSME, HOB, 
and haze prevention. The assessment will be based on the relevance of these 
policy  instruments  to  the  major  environmental  issues  and  trends  in  the 
subregion as defined in activity 1, and the efficiency and effectiveness with 
which the policies are being implemented. Gaps in policies will be identified and 
recommendations will be made, including several that will be included in the 
REP.  The  institutional  capability  of  the  implementing  institutions—their 
mandate, structure, administrative systems, number and skills of personnel, 
logistics,  financial  sustainability,  and  support  linkages—and  their  bias  or 
orientation toward decentralization and degree of participatory management will 
also  be  assessed.  These  institutions  include  the  BIMP-EAGA  Facilitation 
Center,  the  national  secretariats,  BEBC  and  its  secretariat  and  associate 
business  groups,  the  SSME  tri-national  committee,  HOB  technical  working 
groups, and the office in the ASEAN secretariat that manages the ASEAN 
trans-boundary haze work program. The institutional requirements for policy 
implementation  through  standard  setting,  monitoring,  selected  technical 
assistance, country complementation, and self-regulation will be estimated. The 
results will indicate the institutional capabilities and shortfall and go into likely 
interventions under the proposed REP. 
 
(iii)  Activity 3: Formulating a 15-year program. The aim is to draw stakeholder 
inputs and support for the program. In a series of consultation meetings, the 
stakeholders will validate the result of activities 1 and 2, identify the issues, 
define  the  sustainability  indicators  for  the  subregion,  and  propose  future 
courses of action. These local, national, and subregional meetings will result in 
the following: (a) actions to be carried out at the subregional level, (b) actions 
supporting the ASEAN haze program and SSME and HOB and linking these to 
the overall REP, and (c) actions intended to strengthen the capability of BIMP-
EAGA  institutions  to  implement  the  REP.  A  technical  team  will  study  the 
feasibility  of  the  actions  with  the  following  principles  in  mind:  efficiency  of 
resource  use,  equity  of  access,  balance  between  competing  uses,  use  of 
environmentally sound technologies, payment for environmental services, and 
collaboration of stakeholder groups. The REP will run for 15 years in three 5-
year cycles.  
 
(iv)  Activity  4:  Generating  government  support  and  forging  broad 
partnerships for action. The proposed program will be submitted for review to 
the governments of the countries in the subregion and to the BEBC. Their 
representatives and the technical team will consult and agree on any needed 
revisions or adjustments in the program. The program will also be circulated to 
multilateral  and  bilateral  agencies,  private  sector  groups,  and  NGOs.  Their 
suggestions and participation in plan implementation will be sought.

5
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The RETA is estimated to cost $1.7 million, $1.5 million of which will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program.7 The governments of the four member countries will 
each  contribute  $50,000  in-kind  through  counterpart  support  services.  Each  country  will 
finalize its contribution before the RETA implementation. The detailed cost estimates and 
proposed financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the RETA.  The World Wildlife Fund for Nature 
(WWF), through its national organizations operating in the EAGA has the necessary regional 
and national expertise to provide technical and operational services for the RETA under the 
1998  Policy  on  Cooperation  between  ADB  and  NGOs,  and  the  2001  ADB–WWF 
Memorandum of Understanding.  WWF is the world’s largest environmental NGO and has a 
well-established network. Its work in conservation and development is widely recognized, 
including its involvement in on-going initiatives in SSME, HoB and transboundary haze which 
are  part  of  the  proposed  TA.  WWF  has  more  than  15  years  of  work  experience  in  the 
subregion with national organizations in three EAGA countries. It has a proven record of 
successful collaboration with governments, the private sector, donor agencies, NGOs, and 
local  communities;  a  long-established  presence,  particularly  in  biodiversity  hotspots;  and 
available counterpart resources to commit to the RETA. ADB will therefore engage WWF 
through single source selection to undertake the environmental and socioeconomic profiling, 
GIS mapping, and stakeholder consultation meetings.  
 
15.  At  the  regional  level  the  BIMP-EAGA  will  provide  the  institutional  framework  for 
program development.  The EAGA functions through regular meetings of working groups. 
Twice-yearly meetings of senior officials and annual meetings of leaders are held back to back 
with the ASEAN summits. Singapore will be invited by the natural resources cluster of working 
groups to participate as a strategic partner of ASEAN in sector discussions with the EAGA 
countries. The BIMP-EAGA is the institutional home for the RETA, and it will work closely with 
the natural resources cluster and its groups in forestry and the environment, energy, fisheries, 
and agro-industry—all key targets of the RETA. This RETA will be part of the program of the 
natural  resources  cluster,  which  will  coordinate  with  ADB  in  preparing,  overseeing,  and 
facilitating RETA implementation. Any specific activity funded by this RETA will start in a 
particular  member  country  only  after  ADB  has  received  a  no-objection  letter  from  its 
government. 
 
16.  The program planning will require 24 person-months of international consulting and 
56 person-months  of  national  consulting  services.  The  international  consultants  will  be 
selected  and  hired  by  ADB,  and  the  national  consultants  by  WWF,  according  to  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). All procurement 
under the RETA will follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to 
time). Outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION 
 
17.  The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  the  provision  of  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis for program planning 
for Strengthening Sound Environmental Management in the Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia, 
Malaysia, and Philippines East ASEAN Growth Area. 
                                                 
7  Application for cofinancing in the amount of $300,000 for project development will be made to the Global 
Environment Facility (GEF). Four GEF proposals will be prepared for HOB, SSME, forest management, the 
carbon credit pilot project in West Papua, and regional climate change mitigation and adaptation. If approved, the 
amount will be used to supplement the detailed study for specific GEF-eligible projects.

SSME and HOB eco-regional plans and ASEAN haze program (month 
12). 
3.5  Identify and prioritize recommendations to address the issues (month 13). 
3.6  Assess the capability of the existing plans to carry out the 
recommendations and the extent to which they are consistent with 
decentralization and participatory principles (month 13). 
3.7  Define support actions to enhance the existing plans (month 13). 
3.8  Identify opportunities and constraints in carrying out actions (month 13). 
3.9  Carry out feasibility analyses of actions and integrate these into one 
package (month 16).  
 
4.  Generation of Government Support and Wider Partnership  
 
4.1  Consultant with BIMP-EAGA and the government agencies concerned to 
get their formal acceptance of the REP (month 14). 
4.2  Elicit suggestions from private sector groups and NGOs (month 14). 
4.3  Initiate the process of program implementation (month 17). 
4.4  Negotiate  with  donor  agencies  to  secure  funding  commitments  for 
program plan implementation (month 17). 
 
ASEAN = Association of Southeast Asian Nations; BIMP = Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Philippines; 
EAGA = East ASEAN Growth Area; HOB = Heart of Borneo; NGO = nongovernment organization; REP = regional 
environment program; RETA = regional technical assistance; SSME = Sulu-Sulawesi Marine Ecoregion; WWF = 
World Wildlife Fund for Nature.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
1.  The team for phase 1 of the regional technical assistance (RETA) will be supervised by 
the natural resources economist of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to whom the task is 
assigned, and managed by a project team leader. The team, which will operate from the ADB 
headquarters in Manila, will consist of the following: 
 
(i)  team leader and program design expert,  
(ii)  institutional and governance specialist,  
(iii)  economist, and 
(iv)  World  Wildlife  Fund  for  Nature  (WWF)  national  organizations  in  the  Brunei 
Darussalam,  Indonesia,  Malaysia,  Philippines  East  Association  of  Southeast 
Asian Nations (ASEAN) Growth Area (BIMP-EAGA). 
 
 
A.  Team Leader and Program Design Expert  
 
2.  Under the overall direction and guidance of ADB’s natural resources economist assigned 
to manage the RETA, the team leader will provide leadership to the project team toward the 
achievement of the project objectives within the set timetable. Specifically, the team leader will 
be responsible for:  
 
(i)  Providing  leadership  in  the  design  of  the  BIMP-EAGA  regional  environment 
program (REP), and preparing the program document and related papers in 
close cooperation with various stakeholders and partners. 
(ii)  Providing  general  supervision  over  WWF,  the  single-source  contractor  for 
program preparation. 
(iii)  Providing overall direction in the environmental and socioeconomic profiling of 
BIMP-EAGA by preparing the general methodology and outline of the profile 
report in close consultation with ADB and WWF. 
(iv)  Consolidating  the  country  environmental  profiles  into  a  subregional  picture 
showing status, location, threats, and trends.  
(v)  Developing mechanisms to ensure the cooperation of government and other 
relevant stakeholder groups in the country and subregional profiling. 
(vi)  Reviewing the BIMP-EAGA policies and plans, Sulu-Sulawesi Marine Ecoregion 
(SSME) and Heart of Borneo (HOB) eco-regional plans, and the ASEAN haze 
work program to identify gaps and draft recommendations.   
(vii)  Leading  the  preparation  of  a  subregional  environment  program  including  its 
financing strategy, monitoring and evaluation arrangements, and guidance for 
ADB in its implementation.  
(viii)  Designing mechanisms for sustainable financing to support a range of activities 
under the BIMP-EAGA REP. 
(ix)  Designing a monitoring and evaluation framework for REP. 
(x)  In tandem with ADB’s natural resources economist assigned to manage the 
RETA, developing partnerships with donor agencies and coordinating with them 
in  supporting  interventions  to  harmonize  efforts  and  sustain  cooperative 
relationships.  
(xi)  Coordinating  closely  with  governments,  regional  bodies,  international 
development agencies, private sector groups, and other stakeholder groups in 
preparing the REP and generating support for its adoption by BIMP-EAGA.

12   Appendix 3   
(xii)  Assisting ADB in preparing for meetings with senior officials of governments, 
regional bodies, and international development agencies, and participating in 
these meetings.  
(xiii)  Providing technical guidance and direction to the WWF to ensure that its terms of 
reference are complied with. 
(xiv)  Evaluating  the  performance  and  outputs  of  WWF  and  making  appropriate 
recommendations to the ADB Management through ADB’s natural resources 
economist. 
(xv)  Updating the ADB Management through ADB’s natural resources economist on 
the  progress  of  work  through  periodic  reports  and  regular  meetings,  and 
submitting periodic project reports required by the ADB Management through 
ADB's natural resources economist. 
 
B.  Institutional and Governance Specialist 
 
3.  The institutional and governance specialist will conduct the institutional assessment of 
BIMP-EAGA and relevant institutions, provide technical direction and guidance to WWF in the 
socioeconomic profiling and the conduct of participatory processes, and assist the team leader 
in selected activities. Under the overall direction and guidance of ADB’s natural resources 
economist assigned to manage the RETA, the specialist will be responsible for the following:  
 
(i)  Conducting an institutional assessment of BIMP-EAGA organizations, including 
the Facilitation Center, national secretariats, the natural resources cluster group, 
and  the  BIMP-EAGA  Business  Council  and  its  secretariat,  as  well  as  the 
organizational  mechanisms  for  SSME,  HOB,  and  the  ASEAN  haze  work 
program.    
(ii)  Developing options for enhancing the institutional capacity of BIMP-EAGA for 
environmental management and support for the implementation of the SSME and 
HOB eco-regional plans and the ASEAN haze work program. 
(iii)  Providing technical guidance to WWF in: (a) preparing the socioeconomic profile 
and  conducting  participatory  processes,  and  (b)  planning  for  stakeholder 
participation in the preparation of the REP. 
(iv)  Consolidating the country socioeconomic profiles into a subregional picture of 
common trends.  
(v)  Assisting  the  team  leader  in  preparing  the  BIMP-EAGA  REP  and  program 
documents and in supervising WWF.  
(vi)  Assisting the team leader in establishing mechanisms to ensure the cooperation 
of government and other relevant stakeholder groups, negotiating partnerships 
with donor agencies, and coordinating with donors supporting interventions in 
river corridors to harmonize efforts and sustain cooperative relationships.  
 
C.  Economist  
 
4.  The economist will work with the other consultants and WWF in designing a payment 
mechanism for environmental services, and in determining the economic and financial feasibility 
of interventions included in the proposed environmental program. Under the overall direction 
and  guidance  of  ADB’s  natural  resources  economist  assigned  to  manage  the  RETA,  the 
economist will be responsible for the following:

Appendix 3  13
(i)  Working  with  the  program  design  expert,  the  institutional  and  governance 
specialist, and WWF in identifying and designing interventions related to payment 
for environmental services.  
(ii)  Working  with  other  consultants  in  determining  the  economic  and  financial 
feasibility of the interventions proposed for the BIMP-EAGA REP.   
(iii)  Costing  interventions  found  to  be  socially,  environmentally,  technically,  and 
economically feasible and earmarked for inclusion in the environmental plan and 
the entire program package.  
(iv)  Preparing relevant sections of the REP and related reports as required for the 
project.  
 
D.  National Organizations of the World Wildlife Fund for Nature in the East ASEAN 
Growth Area   
 
5.  Under the supervision of the consultants, WWF, through its national organizations, will 
undertake  the  following  tasks:  prepare  country  profiles,  prepare  maps  using  geographic 
information system (GIS) technology, and hold stakeholder meetings in close coordination with 
BIMP-EAGA  national  secretariats  and  the  Facilitation  Center  and  make  all  the  necessary 
arrangements for the meetings. The activities for each task will be as follows:    
 
1.  Environmental Profiling  
 
(i)  Under the guidance of the program design expert, defining the environmental 
indicators to be used in all EAGA countries in determining the environmental 
characteristics of the parts within EAGA and the methodologies and tools to be 
employed. 
(ii)  Collecting secondary data to document the physical and biological conditions of 
the  areas  in  each  country  within  EAGA,  and  filling  gaps  with  primary  data 
gathered though rapid appraisal methods.  
(iii)  Identifying issues and trends in environmental conservation and management in 
each country for areas within EAGA, on the basis of the data gathered.  
(iv)  Reviewing the afforestation and reforestation methods of the Clean Development 
Mechanism (CDM) and preparing CDM projects as part of the REP. 
(v)  Working with the project consultants in identifying and designing interventions 
related to payment for environmental services.  
(vi)  Contributing to the preparation and conduct of stakeholder consultation meetings 
as part of the planning process, in the environment aspect. 
(vii)  Working with the project consultants in assessing the environmental soundness 
and  technical  feasibility  of  the  recommendations  made  in  the  stakeholder 
consultation and planning meetings.  
(viii)  Submitting written country environmental profiles and periodic reports as required 
for the project. 
 
2.  Socioeconomic Profiling   
 
(i)  Under the guidance of the institutional and governance specialist and ADB’s 
Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis, defining the indicators that will be 
used in profiling the socioeconomic characteristics of those parts of the member 
countries within EAGA and the methodologies and tools.  
(ii)  Incorporating in the profiling indicators specific to indigenous peoples including 
but  not  limited  to  the  following:  relations  of  the  dominant  ethnic  group,

14   Appendix 3   
sociocultural  characteristics,  degree  of  acculturation  to  the  dominant  culture, 
rights  to  land  and  natural  resources,  resource  use,  and  legal  framework  for 
rights. 
(iii)  Gathering secondary data to generate a socioeconomic profile of areas in each 
country within EAGA, and filling gaps with data from primary sources using rapid 
appraisal methods.  
(iv)  Identifying  critical  socioeconomic  issues  and  trends  with  bearing  on 
environmental management, in coordination with the consultants. 
(v)  Preparing for stakeholder consultation meetings and conducting these meetings 
with the national consultants.   
(vi)  Assessing the social soundness and feasibility of the interventions recommended 
in the stakeholder meetings. 
(vii)  Preparing an indigenous peoples framework plan for EAGA in compliance with 
ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998). 
(viii)  Submitting a written socioeconomic profile of the parts of each country within 
EAGA and related reports required for the project. 
 
3.  Geographic Information System Mapping 
 
(i)  Reviewing  and  analysing  current  spatial  decision  support  systems  (DSS)  in 
BIMP-EAGA, taking into account work already done by international, regional, 
and national organizations. 
(ii)  Reviewing satellite images and working with the consultants in updating the data 
on the environmental and socioeconomic characteristics of the parts of each 
country  within  EAGA,  using  the  data  collected  for  the  environmental  and 
socioeconomic profiling.   
(iii)  Collecting and developing an image bank of high-resolution digital images of 
critical areas for biodiversity conservation and other potential areas, for project 
feasibility assessment and preparation. 
(iv)  Collecting, analysing, and preparing comparative data sets in the form of maps 
and digital photographs showing the baseline information during the RETA, and 
defining a system for annual assessments on a thematic basis (e.g., forests, 
corridor restoration work, population, and poverty). 
(v)  Establishing data presentation formats following ADB guidelines on logos and 
spelling, and interfacing them with the management information system so that 
data can be made available to partners in a user-friendly format for maps and 
presentations and program implementation. 
(vi)  Collaborating closely with country institutions and partners involved in monitoring 
and spatial mapping.  
(vii)  Producing GIS maps, data sets, reports, and other technical reports ready for 
dissemination to the BIMP-EAGA stakeholders and partners. 
4.  Conduct of Stakeholder Consultation Meetings  
 
(i)  Identifying the stakeholder groups in EAGA that should be consulted in planning 
the proposed REP.  
(ii)  Under  the  guidance  of  the  institutional  and  governance  specialist  and  in 
consultation with the BIMP-EAGA Facilitation Center, preparing the stakeholder 
participation  plan  including  the  program  and  budget  for  the  stakeholder 
consultation meetings.

Appendix 3  15
(iii)  Making the arrangements and providing secretariat and logistical support for the 
conduct of stakeholder consultation meetings in the countries and at the EAGA 
level,  in  coordination  with  the  BIMP-EAGA  national  secretariats  and  the 
Facilitation Center. 
(iv)  Developing a strategy and a program for the conduct of stakeholder consultation 
meetings in the individual member countries, and assisting in the facilitation of the 
meetings at the EAGA level. 
(v)  Documenting  the  proceedings  of  all  stakeholder  consultation  meetings, 
processing the results, and preparing all relevant reports required for the project.
